text: It is worth pointing out that a previous study on the SPR properties of small Ag nanocrystals showed a reverse size dependence of the SPR peak position. As the particle size decreased from 20 nm, the peak position was initially blue-shifted and then, at 12 nm, the position switched to show a red-shift. In contrast, we did not observe such a reversal when the size of our Au nanospheres was decreased to below 10 nm. This difference could be attributed to two possible factors: Firstly, Ag nanoparticles that were used in the previous study were capped by a monolayer of oleylamine and were dispersed in a hydrophobic medium. In comparison, our Au nanospheres were all stabilized by a bilayer of CTAC molecules and were suspended in water. These differences in surface capping group and solvent may contribute to their different SPR properties. Secondly, the Ag particles can be easily oxidized by the oxygen in air to generate an ultrathin layer of Ag2O on their surface. The volume percentage of the oxidation layer will greatly increase as the particle size is decreased to below 10 nm. Based on our previous study, the resultant Ag/Ag2O core–shell particles may exhibit a red-shift of the absorbance peak compared to Ag nanoparticles of the same size with no oxide layer on the surface. Therefore, it is not unreasonable to assume that the Ag nanoparticles had been oxidized and that the presence of an oxide layer could contribute to the observed red-shift of Ag nanoparticle with sizes below 12 nm.

The phenomena could be attributed to the reducing of Hg2+ to Hg0 by Vc and the generating of gold amalgamation on the tips of AuNRs . The surfactant CTAB mainly covered on the transverse sides of AuNRs and had the shielding effect to prevent the forming of gold amalgamation on the transverse walls. Accordingly, the aspect ratio of AuNRs reduced and LPAW underwent a blue shift . When C Vc was in the range of 85.0–385 μM, TPAW underwent a gradual red shift with a slight increasing of A, the reason was that more and more Hg2+ was reduced to Hg0 in the presence of high concentration Vc to form gold amalgamation, which would cause LPAW to disappear, indicating the forming of Au nanospheres.

In order to monitor the growth of AuNRs by TEM, aliquots were removed from the growth solution every hour, their absorbance spectra were measured, and they were incubated with MUTAB for 2 days to ensure that a maximum surface coverage had occurred. TEM images of these rods after 3, 7, and 11 h of growth are shown in Figure 5 (see Figure S2, Supporting Information, for the 5, 9, and 12 h points). Figure 6 details the change in AuNRs dimensions extracted from the TEM images. Specifically, the changes in length (Figure 6A), waist and tip diameter (Figure 6B), and total volume, estimated by assuming a cylindrical structure with diameter averaged between the waist and tips (Figure 6C), are plotted against the growth time. A summary of this information is provided in Table S2 (Supporting Information). After 3 h, AuNRs display the standard cylindrical morphology with the aspect ratio and LSPR peak close to the final values. However, at this point the rods have grown to only about 15% of their final size based on the estimated volume. The linear increase in volume from that point shown in Figure 6A demonstrates that the reduction to metallic gold occurred at a roughly constant rate, assuming that no new nucleation events are taking place in solution. This steady growth in size is in contrast to the “popcorn” model of ascorbic acid-mediated nanorods growth proposed by Edgar and co-workers. This model states that rather than following the traditional assumption that all seed particles grow evenly from the start of the reaction to the end, the seed particles actually lie quiescent for variable amounts of time and then rapidly grow to their final size. This model was supported by the presence of both small and nearly fully grown AuNRs starting from the very beginning of the reaction up until nearly the end, which is clearly not evident in our procedure. However, it may be that due to the reduced growth rate, most seeds that will eventually grow have time to exit the quiescent state within the first few hours of growth while nanorods have only had time to grow ∼15% of their final size. In other words, the rate at which seed particles switch from the quiescent to the growing state appears to be faster than the rate of AuNRs growth.

TEM image of Au nanoparticles was shown in Fig. 4a with an average size of about 20 nm, it can observed that the photochemical method to prepare Au nanoparticles was successful. SEM images of ZnO nanorods films and AuNPs/ZnO nano-composite films were shown in Fig. 4b and Fig. 4c. Fig. 4b shows the uniformly hexagonal shapes of ZnO nanorods with an average diameter of about 50 nm and Fig. 4c shows Au nanoparticles was attached on ZnO nanorods, and the self-assembly method for preparing Au nanoparticles on ZnO nanorods was successful.

Accordingly, in the UV−vis spectra of as-prepared products, the intensity of the third peak caused by the lobes at the tips increases gradually and exceeds that of the LSP peak finally (Figure 10a−c) due to the decrease in the aspect ratio of the Au NR seeds. This is also because the size of the lobes is comparable to the length of as-prepared products (Tables S3 and S4). In addition, the LSP peak was also blue-shifted and has the trend to merge the third peak together.

We calculated RI susceptibilities from the LSPR peak shifts of AuNSs, AgNSs, and Au/PdNSs surrounded by media whose RI range is 1.333–1.400 using the Mie exact solution. As shown in Figure 5C, theoretically estimated RI susceptibilities (SMie) of these nanoparticles well reproduced the order of the experimentally obtained results (Figure 5B). The theoretical SMie of PdNSs is indeed quite high as shown in Table 1. These SMie values were calculated for nanospheres with experimentally obtained diameters in this study (AuNSs, 60 nm; AgNSs, 70 nm; and Au/PdNSs, 73 nm). The same trend is also obtained for nanospheres with an identical diameter (see Supporting Information, Table S1). The experimentally obtained RI susceptibilities are somewhat smaller than the theoretical ones because the susceptibilities were measured for nanoparticles immobilized on a quartz substrate surface whose RI is fixed, resulting in reduced overall susceptibility to the RI changes in the bulk solution, which is called the “substrate effect”.

Figure 3a demonstrates four typical PL spectra and their corresponding scattering spectra for individual GNBs. Obviously, the longitudinal plasmon resonance in the PL spectrum resemble closely with its scattering spectrum independent of the aspect ratio. As shown in Figure 3b, a typical longitudinal resonance spectrum can be perfectly fitted by a Lorentz function (blue line), revealing that the PL is really from a single GNB. We note that there is a slight difference between the PL and scattering spectra both in terms of peak position and line-shape. This difference has also been observed in gold spheres, disks and nanorods, which was attributed either to higher availability of excited electrons closer to the initial energy of the laser excitation, or to dynamic and photoinduced charging processes. However, the underlying mechanism needs to be further investigated.

GNFs in this study were prepared from Pd or Pt NPs at 80 °C. As the size of the seeds increases, the overall size of GNFs also increases and the resonant peaks red-shift, with Pt seeds of 123 nm in diameter producing a resonance peak at 1148 nm (Fig. 1k, green line). When growth was conducted at room temperature, it was very slow, taking more than 2 hours to complete, and the tips were not as sharp as those prepared at a higher temperature (ESI, Fig. S1†).

However, Wei et al. [28] have pointed out that the length of GNRs was significantly increased when the concentration of CTAB was raised from 25 to 200 mM. Moreover, Ye et al. [8] also reported that in order to synthesize the high AR of GNRs at a given pH with the addition HCl using 5-bromosalicylic acid as the additive, modified dimensions of GNR length and width were obtained when reducing the amount of seed particles. In addition, the AR of GNRs could be further tuned by altering the amount of AgNO3 added. These results from previous studies [8,28] do not correspond with the present research; the difference between these results is likely due to the total volume of growth solution covariation for the present study.

The size and shape of GNRs obtained at different pH values were also characterized by TEM (Fig. 3D). The statistics on the length, diameter, and aspect ratio of the GNRs are also shown in Table 1. It can be seen that the aspect ratio increases first and reaches the maximum of 4.52 at pH 11.16 and then decreases, which is consistent with the UV-Vis spectra. Moreover, the aspect ratio has a linear relationship with LLSPR peak position (Fig. S2†), which is in line with previous reports. The diameters of GNRs at pH 5.85 are 13.8 nm and are much larger than that at other pH values where their diameters are constantly 9.5 nm. It is probably because at pH 5.85 most of the added seeds are oxidized and only a few finally became gold nanorods. From TEM images, we also can see that nanorod yield is very high and can be affected by pH value. In fact, with NaOH addition between 22.5 and 100 μL, the impurity in the samples is less than ∼2%. If the pH was adjusted higher, the purity gradually decreased, since nanocubes and other irregular nanoparticles were formed. More importantly, the morphology of GNRs is not affected by the dramatic change of pH value. The “chop stick” shaped GNRs only turned into rods with a small narrowing at the rod center at extremely high pH. The “dogbone” or “toast” shaped nanoparticles were not observed in our studies. As shown in Table 1, the uniform GNRs have narrow size distributions. For example, GNRs obtained at pH 11.83 exhibit the sizes of 36.8 ± 3.9 nm in length and 9.0 ± 1.5 nm in diameter. Thus, we can conclude that high quality GNRs are readily prepared by using H2O2 as the reducing agent.

In our case, rods produced by borohydride reduction had a transverse diameter of approximately 7 nm, and a longitudinal diameter of between 12 and 17 nm. Consistent with what has previously been reported by Jana and, more recently, by Ali, the aspect ratio of these “small” gold nanorods could be controlled by varying the concentration of sodium borohydride used in the synthesis (Figure 6). By decreasing the borohydride concentration used in the synthesis from 1.5 to 0.05 mM, the aspect ratios of the rods were increased from 2.0 (LSPR = 700 nm) to 3.0 (LSPR = 795 nm). The aspect ratio 2 AuNRs have a transverse diameter of 6.6 ± 1.0 nm and a length of 13.5 ± 2.2 nm, giving an average aspect ratio of 2.0 ± 0.1 (N = 100). The aspect ratio 3 AuNRs have a transverse diameter of 6.1 ± 1.2 nm and a length of 16.5 ± 3.8 nm, giving an average aspect ratio of 2.8 ± 0.5 (N = 100).

TEM images (Figure 1) of the products prepared in the presence of silver ions at a growth time of 24–48 h indicate that the final products were branched particles with 3–6 branches. Longer growth periods resulted in more branches per particle. The average size of the NP core is 30–40 nm, and the branches can grow up to 50 nm. Scheme 1 presents the overall synthetic process. Au NPs with spherical morphologies were initially used as seeds in the Au growth solution. As the Au seeds grew, the silver cation complexes were adsorbed on the Au surface and functioned as growth inhibitors. Hence, after a growth time of 24 h (Figure 1a), irregular plate-like Au NPs with few short branches were observed because the capping ability of the silver ions results in the blocking of most of the Au NP surface. Thus, the remaining unblocked parts on the surface of irregular Au NPs expanded in a specific direction, which eventually formed branches. The diameter of the Au NP cores increased only slightly between a growth time of 24 and 48 h. Continuous growth predominantly occurred on the corners of the irregular plate-like Au NPs and in a particular direction, which results in branching (Figure 1b and 1c). Silver capping is effective on specific facets of initial Au crystallites and results in growth of branches rather than expansion of the core. HRTEM was performed to characterize branched Au NPs in detail and identify their crystalline boundaries (Figure 1c). Visible boundaries reveal that a branched Au NP consists of numerous single Au crystallites. The boundaries are in the middle of the branches, which indicates the occurrence of preferential growth along the boundary of two crystallites. This result suggests that Au NPs initially grew in the form of irregular hexagonal or pentagonal multicrystalline structures (Figure 1a), which function as initial intermediate products in the growth of branched Au NPs. If the AgNO3 concentration in the growth solution is 0.04 mM and the synthesis period does not exceed ∼42 h, then most of the formed Au NPs have two-dimensional (2D) star-like structures with 3–5 branches (Figure 1c). When the growth time is increased to 48 h or when the AgNO3concentration is 0.05 mM, more irregular three-dimensional (3D) Au NSs with more than 6 branches are formed (Figure 1b). The HRTEM image of a single branch (Figure 1d) shows lattice fringes with an average interfacet distance of ∼0.23 nm, which corresponds to the space between the ⟨111⟩ planes of the Au face-centered cubic (fcc) structure. This result indicates preferential growth on the ⟨111⟩ facets, which is consistent with previous reports on Au NP synthesis in the presence of Ag+ cations. The crystalline structure of Au NPs was analyzed using synchrotron XRD (Figure 1e). The diffraction peaks of an as-prepared sample coincide with those of a standard Au (ICSD 58393). On the basis of the Scherrer equation, the primary crystallite size was estimated at 16.2 nm from the fwhm of the ⟨111⟩ reflex, which is considerably smaller than the particle sizes observed by TEM. These results confirm that each of the Au NSs is multicrystalline, i.e., constructed from several single crystals. Following formation of branched Au NPs, chitosan was used to replace CTAB as a stabilizer on the Au surface for subsequent application.

GNRs were synthesized by a seed-mediated method. Similar to older reports3, every change in the amount of each reagent in growth solution led to changes in GNR’s size and aspect ratio. In order to control the GNR’s aspect ratio, only the silver nitrate amounts were changed. The amounts of all the other reagents were kept constant. An aliquant of 50 to 60 μl of 0.01 M AgNO3 was used to obtain rods with aspect ratio of 4. Additionally, the results show that the synthesis temperature is an important parameter to provide majorly monodispersed rods with a very low amount of byproducts. Therefore, all of the synthesis steps were done at a constant temperature of 30 °C.

The visible colors and optical properties of AuNPs are known to be strongly sensitive to their size and shape. As shown in the photographs of the aqueous solutions of the AuNPs (Fig. 1a), the AuNPs exhibited distinct colour variation depending on their size and shape. The optical properties of the AuNPs were characterized by UV-Vis spectroscopy (Fig. 1b–d). For Au nanospheres and Au nanostars, the NPs displayed obvious surface plasmon resonance (SPR) peaks ranging from 500 to 800 nm and their SPR peaks red-shifted as the nanoparticle size increased. The maximum absorption peaks of sphere-40, sphere-70, sphere-110, star-40, star-70 and star-110 were observed at 532, 544, 558, 637, 711 and 790 nm, respectively. In contrast to Au nanospheres and Au nanostars, Au nanorods had two SPR peaks in the UV-Vis spectra, which corresponded to their transverse and longitudinal modes. Rod-40, rod-70 and rod-110 exhibited a strong longitudinal SPR peak at 606, 864 and 882 nm wavelengths, respectively. As the aspect ratio of rod-40 was much lower than that of rod-70 and rod-110 (see below), the spectrum of rod-40 was obviously different from that of rod-70 and rod-110.

Generally, the formation of NP involves two main stages, nucleation and growth. In our system, part of precursor (Au3+) is reduced in the nucleation stage and small-sized Au NPs form which will serve as seeds. In the growth stage, the rest of Au3+ is further reduced to Au atoms which deposit on those preformed small-sized NPs (seed) surface and selectively or additionally nucleate to create new NPs. When additional nucleation occurs largely, the product is always polydispersed due to inhomogenous growth. In most cases, the selective deposition on the seed surface dominates due to the nucleation barrier and self-catalytic effect, generating monodispersed colloid NPs. In our case, the HAADF images show that these prepared decahedral NPs (Fig. 5 and S12 in the ESI†) have uniform size, indicating that the additional nucleation is not significant. Hypothetically, the nucleation and growth stage separate completely. That is to say, no additional nucleation occurs in the growth stage and all newly formed atoms grow on the seed surface. According to the classical nucleation and growth theory built by LaMer et al., the reaction temperature-dependent size change in our system can be explained with eqn (1). where M, Mn, and Mg represent the total amount of Au precursor, the consumed amount of Au3+ in the nucleation stage and the consumed amount of Au3+ in the growth stage respectively. In our experiment, M is kept unchanged. Low reaction temperature causes slow nucleation rate. Therefore, Mn and the number of formed seed NPs in the nucleation stage are small, indicating that Mg increases with decreasing reaction temperature. As a result, most of the precursor is reduced to atoms in the growth stage which selectively grow on a small amount of seeds, producing large sized Au decahedra. Otherwise, if a high reaction temperature is used, Mn increases and Mg reduces, which favors the formation of small-sized Au decahedra.

The rate of chemical reactions also played an important role. It is possible that a fast reaction may build up enough material (large ZnO oversaturation) to continually sustain the high energy paths, such as the homogeneous nucleation and the β path. In fact, simultaneously achieving homogeneous and heterogeneous nucleation is known to lead to a large size polydispersity of the resulting NPs. Typically, slow reactions are preferred in the literature to achieve better synthetic control. A fast reaction may promote a large number of nucleation sites per seed, but if it is too fast, it may also cause homogeneous nucleation, leading to polydispersed NPs. In practice, it would be very challenging to maintain the ZnO oversaturation in the small window between Chomo and Cβ (Figure 8c). Thus, reducing σ13 is a more practical solution for promoting multiple nucleation sites (Figure 8b). This approach was effective for the core–shell seed@oxide NPs in our system. For example, the temporal evolution of the Au@ZnO NPs showed that thin ZnO shells (5 nm) already formed at the initial stage and did not form by growing and merging isolated ZnO petals subsequently.

Firstly, the size and morphology of gold nanoparticles and core–shell nanocomposites were determined using transmission electron microscopy. Fig. 1(a and b) represents the TEM images of spherical gold and silica nanoparticles respectively while Fig. 1(c) shows the image of SiO2@Au core–shell NCs. It was found that average gold nanoparticle size was ~30 nm and that of silica particles was ~420 nm which increased to ~480 nm for nanocomposites. Fig. 1(c) clearly indicates that the SiO2@Au core–shell NCs synthesized were speckled particles i.e., they retain the gold particle size as was used in the formation of core–shell particles. However, they appear as separate particles with nanogaps between them and create a large number of adsorption sites for detection of foreign ions i.e. metal ions.

Fluorescence images were obtained and propagation lengths determined by fitting the fluorescence decay for a range of laser frequencies for individual gold and silver wires. The experimental results are summarized in Figure 3, with the points showing the average values and the error bars showing the standard deviations associated with the measured results from four wires. This distribution of propagation lengths is related to the distribution of nanowire diameters in the sample since, as we show below, the propagation length decreases as the diameter decreases.

The SERS properties of Au NCs were studied using 4-ATP and flusilazole (a kind of pesticide usually used on fruits) molecules. Fig. S8 (ESI†) shows the normal Raman spectrum of a 4-ATP molecule and the SERS spectra of 4-ATP molecules adsorbed on the films of Au NCs with sizes of 40 nm, 87 nm, 147 nm, and 242 nm. At the excitation laser wavelength of 638 nm, multiple Raman bands between 800 and 1800 cm−1 are strongly enhanced. On the basis of the standard Raman spectrum of 4-ATP, the two strong Raman peaks at 1075 and 1575 cm−1 can assigned to the vibration modes of νCS (a1 mode) and νCC (a1 mode) of 4-ATP, respectively, while the other three Raman peaks at 1142, 1391, and 1437 cm−1 are assigned to the vibration ag mode of DMAB. The formation of DMAB during SERS measurement is due to the SPR-assisted activation of 3O2 on films of Au NCs. The SERS activities of as-prepared Au NCs increased and decreased with their sizes, which is proved to be influenced by the crystal size; the largest SERS enhancement is observed for the Au NCs with an average size of around 147 nm. We also estimated the SERS properties of Au NCs using flusilazole molecules as probes (Fig. S9, ESI†). Au NCs with diameters of 147 nm still show the strongest SERS properties, which is consistent with the results using 4-ATP as the detecting molecules. Thus, the monodisperse Au NCs with precise sizes synthesized by this method could be greatly used in the study in SERS fields.

According to this equation, the AR of the AuNRs was calculated to be 3, which corresponded to the result of FESEM. After coated by CuO NPs, the strong longitudinal absorption peaks shifted to a longer wavelength of ~ 720 nm. As CuO possesses a higher refractive index (nCuO = 2.63) than water (nwater = 1.33) [36], the CuO coating is likely to induce an increase in the effective dielectric constant of the surrounding medium of Au NRs, which resulted in the changes in scattering and absorption, and finally caused the red shift in the UV–vis absorption spectra [37]. Moreover, the absorption intensity of the Au NRs-CuO nanocomposites decreased relative to Au NRs, which may be caused by the CuO NPs that can weaken the gold surface electron oscillation, and subsequently affect the intensity of the SPR [38].

Fig. 4 a corresponds to the TEM images of AuNRs dispersion in the water having length ≈53–60 nm and width ≈20–25 nm (aspect ratio ≈ 2.5) along with some square or rectangular shaped particles (SI-Fig. 2). MeOH addition resulted in the decrease of inter particle distance among the adjacent NRs and showed parallel alignment to a little extent (Fig. 4b). Formation of small groups of NRs with random or haphazard arrangement (Fig. 4c) and a large clump of aggregate (Fig. 4d) relative to distantly positioned rods in aqueous media are also seen in MeOH dispersion.

To investigate the effect of NP size and surface coating on their cellular uptake, gold NPs were prepared by reducing the gold salt using citric acid as a reducing agent. The size of the NPs was controlled by manipulating the ratio of gold salt to reducing agent. Figure 2, A shows the TEM images of gold NPs with mean diameters of 14.2 (±5.3), 50.4 (±7.3), 74.3 (±9.3) nm. UV-visible spectra of NPs of diameter 14, 50, and 74 nm showed peak absorbance at 517, 534, and 550 nm, respectively (see Figure 2, B). Gel electrophoresis analysis showed three separate bands for the different-sized populations of NPs, indicating the uniformity of their size distributions (see Supplement S3 in the online version of this article). The surface of the NPs was modified with BSA to determine the effect of protein coating on their cellular uptake and processing. FTIR spectra confirmed the presence of protein on the surface of the gold NPs as shown in Figure 2, C. The addition of 10% NaCl into suspensions of gold NPs with protein coating showed no color change, whereas uncoated gold NP suspensions aggregated and turned blue with the addition of salt as illustrated in Figure 2, D. In addition, as summarized in Figure 2, E, the hydrodynamic diameter, zeta potential, and peak absorbance wavelength of gold NP suspensions with and without protein coating were measured to further verify the presence of proteins on the NPs. The number of BSA molecules per NP was calculated using BCA assay kit (Thermo Scientific) and found to be 21, 275, and 600 for NPs of 14, 50, and 74 nm in diameter, respectively.

The interpretation of these findings is complex. However it may be rationalized by considering the key role of Ag+ species in the synthesis of polyhedral nanocrystals, as demonstrated by Wu et al. [33]. It was proposed that silver was present in the form of a soluble complex and that this complex has a high propensity to bind to the nanorods surface. Silver is present in the growth solution as Ag (I) and cannot be reduced by ascorbic acid to its metallic form in the presence of CTAB. Silver ions act as a strongly binding surfactants which protect the facets from a further growth, ending in bipyramids, with the side (1 0 0) facets tilted toward the (1 1 1) facets [33]. These findings were obtained by varying the concentration of AgNO3 in the growth solution. In the present study, the concentration of AgNO3 did not vary, including in S1-G1 and S2-G1. As a consequence, the morphological change (rod in S1-G1 and polyhedral in S2-G1) could not be attributed to an effect of AgNO3, as reported in the Letter of Wu et al. [33], but may be explained according to a similar mechanism. It is likely that the preferential deposition of AgI-CTAB complex and PP molecules occurs on sites located on the rod end facets. This may stop the growth process in the (1 1 1) direction to form gold nano-hexagons of about 98 nm of diameter, which are very similar to bipyramids.

We recorded UV/Vis extinction spectra for Au nanospheres with different diameters to investigate their LSPR properties as a function of their size. As shown in Figure 5 aonly one major absorbance peak appeared in the spectrum for each sample of Au nanospheres. The intensity of the peak became stronger as the particle size increased. Peak intensity depends on both the nanoparticle concentration and on the extinction cross-section of an individual nanoparticle. The extinction cross-section is directly proportional to the volume of the nanoparticle. When the diameter increases, the volume of a nanoparticle becomes larger, thus resulting in an increase in the resonance peak intensity. For the calculation of molar absorptivity, see the Supporting Information. We also calculated the UV/Vis spectra for Au nanospheres with different sizes by using Mie theory. As shown in Figure 5 bthe calculated peak positions displayed a similar trend to what was observed experimentally. The peak position exhibited a slight red-shift with the increase in diameter for both the experimental and calculated data (Figure 5 c). Expanded versions of both experimental and calculated UV/Vis extinction spectra for the 5, 7, and 10 nm Au nanospheres can be found in the Supporting Information, Figure S5. Despite showing a similar trend, some minor differences between the experimental and calculated values of peak positions could be observed. These discrepancies could be attributed to the slight polydispersity in the sizes in a real sample. In addition, the theoretical calculations were based on the assumption that the particle had a perfect spherical profile. In fact, the surface of the Au nanospheres may contain small facets. Such a deviation in shape could also cause a shift in the SPR peak position.

From our observed results, we propose a mechanistic step in gold nanoparticle formation that incorporates seed-mediated nucleation. From kinetic evidence Finke et al. proposed continuous slow nucleation with fast autocatalytic growth for transition-metal nanocluster formation.26 This proposed mechanism can explain the observed narrow size distribution due to the separation of nucleation and growth in time.26 Our results for gold nanoparticle synthesis suggest that nucleation is a slow process at the beginning of the reaction, followed by simultaneous nucleation and growth mediated by the early nucleations. Thus, nucleation rapidly increases as the reaction progresses, then slows down, and eventually stops (so the particle concentration becomes constant) as growth predominates. Accordingly, we propose a two-step mechanism: an initial slow nucleation, followed by a burst of nucleation mediated by seeds and growth (Figure 9).

A similar trend can be found for the SSA additive except that it required an even higher SSA/CTAB ratio (0.15) to start the nanorod growth. However, the nanorod can grow to an aspect ratio as large as ∼1:5 (or longitudinal SPR at 870 nm, Figure 1, parts C and J). Again, further increasing the SSA concentration grew the nanorod more isotropically (Figure 1K).

The layer-by-layer samples prepared with non-spherical GNP shapes were tested for sucrose sensitivity with some showing increased sensitivity compared to solution. Fig. 8 shows results of the LSPR monitoring with CTAB-coated rods/PSS (filled red rod), PC-coated triangular prims/pDADMAC (filled green triangle), pDADMAC-coated octahedra/PSS (open black hexagon), and PC-coated spheres/pDADMAC (open orange circle) samples glued inside a cuvette as sucrose was titrated in and stirred. The sensitivities were determined to be 52.5 (CTAB-coated rod/PSS), 31.8 (PC-coated prism/pDADMAC), 68.6 (pDADMAC-coated octahedra/PSS), and 59.8 nm/RIU (PC-coated sphere/pDADMAC). In comparison to the solution state, the CTAB-coated rod sensitivity was 19.1 times higher in solution (1002.4 nm/RIU) and the PC-coated prisms were 4.6 times higher in solution (145.0 nm/RIU), suggesting hindered access within the multi-layers. The CTAB-coated rods have a high aspect ratio, may pack together tightly resulting in lowered sensitivity in the layer-by-layer thin film. The PVP films reduced this sensitivity 3.8-fold. Different self-assembly techniques could help in increasing the degrees of freedom in thin film samples [47]. The PC-coated prisms showed good coverage with pDADMAC in the AFM image and their UV-vis spectra however showed little aggregation. Thick coverage with a sucrose impermeable polymer may explain why these prisms were much less sensitive than monolayers of prisms affixed using PEI, PSS, and poly(allylamine hydrochloride) [46].

Chitosan-protected NCs (chit-NCs) were obtained in water by using the galvanic replacement-based procedure (Ref. [17]). Briefly, chitosan-capped Ag nanoparticles (chit-AgNPs) were synthesized through a classic reduction method, based on the reduction of AgNO3 by NaBH4 in the presence of chitosan, acting as both stabilizing and protecting agent. In particular, 8.6 ml of a 9.3 mM 1%-acetic acid solution of chitosan were added to an aqueous solution of AgNO3 (10.2 ml, 6.2 mM). Then, an aqueous solution of NaBH4 (1.1 ml, 56 mM) was added drop by drop. The reaction was performed at ambient temperature under vigorous magnetic stirring. Under these experimental conditions, we obtained stable NPs exhibiting irregular shapes and a size distribution centered at 26 nm with σ + = 24 nm and σ − = 13 nm. Fig. 1 shows a typical TEM image and the statistical distribution of the particle size.

To further investigate the role of iodide and silver ions, a series of experiments were carried out. The new seeds (Figures 9 and S6) were first prepared by tuning the amounts of iodide ions in the growth solution in the “seed-mediated” growth for Au NRs. The aspect ratio of the Au NRs was decreased gradually from 2.5 to 1.5, and spherical crystal was obtained eventually. The blue shift of the LSP peak further confirmed the decrease in the aspect ratio of the Au crystals (Figure 9). All {111} facets of the new seeds were then covered by iodide ions before use. When these as-prepared seeds were separately added into the growth solution containing silver ions (0.06 mM), nanostructured Au crystals with lobes grown from {111} should be formed accordingly. As expected, dogbone-like Au crystals of short aspect ratio (Figures 10 and S7) were obtained. When the aspect ratio of the Au NRs seeds approached ∼1.5, four horn-shaped cubic or cuboid Au crystals were prepared. When spherical crystals were used as seeds, spherical crystals with many thorns on them as well as bipyramids were synthesized. The diameter of the spherical part was ∼40 nm, which is bigger than that of seeds with a diameter of about 26 nm. The length of the horns was in the range of 5−10 nm. It is well-known that the surface of the spherical crystals is composed of {111} and {100} facets. Therefore, the horns are grown from {111} facets, whose growth was also accelerated due to the presence of iodide absorbed on them. This further confirmed that lobes were grown from the {111} facets on the tips of the Au NRs.

Au nanoparticle formation was monitored through time-dependent UV/Vis measurements, which detected the surface plasmon band absorbance (Figure 2). The surface plasmon peaks appeared earlier, that is to say there was faster formation of nanospheres, in the absence of PVP. For example, under the conditions corresponding to Figure 1 (a and c), the respective absorbance maxima were reached at about 10 and 3 min. On the contrary, employing PVP prolonged the growth of the absorbance peaks. In the presence of PVP (Figure 1 (e and g)), particles were formed at similar rates with or without citrate ions. A formation–dissolution process was observed for spherical and icosahedral nanoparticles. Depletion of the surface plasmon band was seen following the appearance of the absorbance peak, accompanied by the formation of an increasingly opaque red colloid. Complete disappearance of the absorbance band down to background took 48 h. Taking Au icosahedra obtained under the conditions in Figure 1 e as an example, Figure 3 a shows the evolution of the UV/Vis spectra as a function of time. TEM images were acquired to monitor nanoparticle formation at different stages of the reaction (Figure 4). Icosahedral Au appeared early (2 min) with a size of approximately 5.5 nm, and then gradually grew to approximately 8 nm after 40 min. Subsequently, the size of the Au nanoparticles slowly decreased to 4.5 nm after 360 min, at which point the morphology appeared to be a mixture of icosahedral and spherical single-crystalline shapes. The dissolution of Au icosahedra is believed to occur through an etching process on their highly active twinned boundary regions, leaving behind spherical nanoparticles.

Figure 2 shows representative TEM images of the carbon-supported AuNPs synthesised and used in this work. Well-dispersed AuNPs were observed in all samples. However, remarkable differences in particle size were found, as expected from the different synthetic methodologies used. The AuNPs prepared by the reduction of HAuCl4 with ice-cold NaBH4 in the presence of citrate had a quasi-spherical particle shape with an average particle size of approximately 5 nm (Figure 2 a). A similar quasi-spherical particle shape was also found for AuNPs prepared by the standard citrate method, however, as expected, their particle size was much larger at approximately 30 nm (Figure 2 b). The AuNPs prepared by addition of NaOH in the presence of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and ascorbic acid show a well-defined octahedral shape but also a certain degree of truncation. The average particle size of these octahedral AuNPs was approximately 40–45 nm (Figure 2 c). This size matches well the expected particle size at the reaction temperature used. Finally, the AuNPs prepared using the Au seed-mediated method adopted a preferred cubic shape with a particle size of 40–45 nm (Figure 2 d).

Fig. 1 illustrates an SEM image of the as-prepared Au/ITO at high magnification. As can be seen, many gold nanoparticles, namely gold nanospheres of 50–60 nm diameter and gold nanorods of 600–700 nm length, are attached directly onto the ITO surface with this seed mediated growth approach. The cyclic voltammetric measurements in 0.5 M H2SO4 indicate that this Au/ITO exhibits the characteristic peaks of the bulk gold electrode, namely an oxidation peak starting at ca. +1.2 V in the positive scan and a reduction peak at ca. +0.9 V in the reverse scan, whereas there is no Faradaic current on the bare ITO electrode (Fig. 2 ). According to the area of the reduction peak , the deposited Au surface area is estimated to be 6.1 × 10−3 cm2 for this gold nanoparticle-attached ITO, almost 20% of the geometric area of ITO. Considering that the as-prepared Au/ITO surface provided attractive electrochemical and electrocatalytic features , we immobilized Mb on this Au/ITO to observe the direct electron transfer of Mb.

Deliverability of larger nanoparticles to cells or tissues in vivo may be limited by colloidal instability and rapid clearance by the reticuloendothelial system. For example, smaller Au NPs (10 nm) achieved improved vascular retention and organ distribution, while larger NPs (50, 100, and 250 nm) were only located within the liver, spleen, and blood, after intravenous injection in rats. Moreover, in vivo delivery to bone tissue requires transport through ∼100–400 nm diameter canaliculi with ∼40–100 nm available fluid space due to the presence of cellular processes and a pericellular matrix that limits diffusion to molecules with an effective diameter less than 10 nm. Therefore, limitations of the Au NP size on delivery will be dependent upon many factors, including the intended application. Intracellular delivery of Au NPs is complex and also dependent on the functional ligands. For example, cellular internalization was shown to be greatest for 50 nm Au NPs compared to smaller or larger Au NPs due to optimal ligand surface density relative to cell surface receptors. Therefore, the ideal particle diameter for delivery may be highly dependent on the application, including the cells or tissues targeted and required surface functionalization.

In conclusion, we have prepared three different type coated AuNRs with two different aspect ratios. While the zeta potential did not change with changes in aspect ratios the l-SPR band position changed significantly with changes in the coating material for the larger aspect ratio AuNRs. This has been attributed to the larger sensitivity of larger aspect ratio rods towards the dielectric medium. The binding of a negatively photosensitizer Cp 6 with these AuNRs resulted in coating specific reduction in the zeta potential. The spectroscopic properties of the drug also depended upon the nature of the coating. While the polymer (PDDAC & PAH) coating affects only the radiative rates of the drug the CTAB coating resulted in decrease of both radiative and nonradiative rates. Interestingly, the decrease in radiative rates was observed to be much higher in presence of PAH coated rods as compared to PDDAC coated rods. The observed changes has been attributed to the difference in the distance between the Cp 6 and the AuNR surface which gets modified with additional layers of coated materials and also to the different chemical structure of the polymers PAH and PDDAC. The nature of the coated material was also observed to modulate the photostability of the drug. However the effect of changing the l-SPR spectral position did not affected the photophysical and photobleaching properties of the drug.

Platinum nanostructures of ca. 20 nm in diameter, with dendritic morphology and two different porosity degrees (see Fig. S1, ESI†) were synthesized by thermolytic reduction of Pt(acac)2 in DMF, in the presence of PEI. As previously reported, by changing the concentration of metal precursor Pt dendrites with different ratios of branch volume to total volume (30% and 22%) were obtained (see ). The particles are also known to be polycrystalline, with interconnected arms branching in various orientations. The presence of PEI on the particle surface provided a highly positive ζ-potential (+44 mV) and prolonged colloidal stability in water.

The catalysts were synthesized via three steps. For the former structure, partial galvanic replacement of the silver cubes with platinum and gold precursors yielded AuPt–Ag alloy hollow cubes. Subsequent chalcogenization with S2– and cationic exchange with Cd2+ yielded AuPt/CdS hollow cubes. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-angle annular dark-field-scanning electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) data show that the structures are completely converted from silver cubes to AuPt–Ag alloy hollow cubes, AuPt/Ag2S hollow cubes, and eventually AuPt/CdS hollow cubes, respectively, with the preservation of the cubic frameworks (Supporting Information, Figures S1–S3, and Figure 2a–c). The resultant AuPt/CdS hollow cubes have an average edge size of 66 ± 10 nm with an average wall thickness of 10 ± 3 nm. Individual hollow cubes have a rough surface with coarse domains (Figure 2b). The HRTEM image shows that the particles possess polycrystalline nature with single-crystal domains of CdS (Figure 2c). The elemental mapping image indicates that Au, Pt, S, and Cd components are distributed evenly over the hollow structure (Supporting Information, Figure S4). The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) data show that some compositional variations of Pt and Au exist in individual particles, although the total atomic % of Pt and Au is invariable (Supporting Information, Figure S5).

These NPs are also graded in particle size by the DLS and the average particle size appears 88.5 nm (Fig. 6(b)) with ζ-potential +24.3 mV (Fig. 6(c)) showing that Aliquat 336 makes multi-faceted NPs as positively charged NPs. Obviously, the particle size by DLS analysis is larger (almost double) than the particle size by TEM analysis (average 43.44 nm), which may be attributed to small aggregation in the aqueous solution. The difference between the particle size obtained from DLS experiment and the sum of two closed-by particles from TEM image (as shown in Fig. 4(b)) is 1.63 nm. That is almost double of the ligand layer measured from TEM images (∼ 0.8 nm).

The synthetic routes of Au NP-PD nanohybrids from the five types of Au NPs via surface-initiated ATRP are illustrated in Scheme 1. The immobilization of the ATRP initiator on the surface is the first and essential step for the functionalization of Au NPs. As reported earlier, BSA-Br was synthesized by the reaction of BSA and α-bromoisobutyric acid (BIBA) in the presence of EDAC and NHS. Subsequently, Au NP-Br was produced via the interaction of Au NPs with BSA-Br, where the introduced alkyl halide groups were the initiation sites. Well-defined Au NP-PDs were then synthesized via ATRP of DMAEMA from Au NP-Br. By controlling the amount of feed DMAEMA monomers and ATRP time, Au NP-PDs with different lengths of PDMAEMA chains on the surface were fabricated. For comparison, two types of Au NP-PDs of various morphologies with the weight ratios (45% and 65% as determined by TGA) of PDMAEMA were produced, namely Au NP-PD1 and Au NP-PD2, respectively. The TGA characterization of the typical Au NP-PDs was described earlier in our previous work.

In this work we have observed that the presence of seed can lead to nanoparticle products smaller than the seed, suggesting that seeds promote nucleation. This is a problem that other workers have observed.53-55 However, controlling the rate of reagent addition directly influenced the product particle size and width of its distribution. Slow addition of a dilute solution of reducing agent suppressed additional nucleation, and we obtained larger particles with improved monodispersity in the size range of 20−100 nm (Tables 3 and 4). Additional nucleations can also be minimized by adjusting the ratio of seed to metal salt. For example, ascorbic acid-reduced gold nanoparticles prepared by fast addition generally showed a broad size distribution (22 ± 10 nm, Figure 3F) when no seed was present; the presence of seed can improve monodispersity when growth predominates over nucleation (set A, Figure 3A, 20 ± 6 nm). The size distributions we obtained are all similar to those achieved by the Natan group, who employed a similar seed-mediated growth method.17d

To further investigate the nanocrystal growth process, a tiny drop of the growth solution in vial B was withdrawn at various times after the growth solution in vial A was transferred to vial B to examine the intermediate products formed. The intermediate structures should be quite representative of the actual particle morphologies in the growth solution because nanoparticle growth was conducted at room temperature. Figure 7 presents the TEM images of the intermediate products observed in the formation of 125 nm octahedral gold nanocrystals. The seed particle shown has a size of 6–7 nm. In just 5 s after transfer of the solution in vial A to vial B, seed particles had rapidly grown to around 15 nm in size; (111) lattice fringes with a d spacing of 2.36 Å were measured. At 30 s, fractal or aggregated structures that surrounded a growing nanocrystal appeared. Such structures become more extensive at 45 s. The twisted structures were composed of gold, as evidenced by their (111) and (200) lattice fringes (see Figure S8 in the Supporting Informartion). After 1 min of reaction, fairly large central cores had formed but the surrounding aggregated gold structures continued to incorporate into the developing nanocrystals. Particle shapes started to emerge. This type of extensive wormlike structures has been observed from 5 s to 20 min into the gold nanoplate formation process synthesized by a thermal growth approach. The twisted structures that surround developing Pd shells have also been found 60 s into the growth of Au Pd core–shell nanocrystals. These results strongly indicate that this growth mechanism is common to the formation of faceted metallic nanocrystals. From 2 to 4 min, some faceted nanocrystals without the external aggregated structures were obtained. Their morphologies may be suggestive of the formation of octahedral nanocrystals but still look quite different from the final shape. Particle size continued to grow to around 80 nm after 4 min of reaction, but they were still appreciably smaller than the final products. Interestingly, many aggregated gold structures around the central nanocrystals appeared again in the 5 and 7 min samples. This supply of new gold atom source in the form of fused structures enabled the nanocrystals to grow to their final dimensions. The 7 min particles exhibited a more identifiable octahedral structure despite the presence of the fused structures. It is possible that this mode of growth process persisted in the first 7 min of reaction, even though some clean intermediate particles like those observed in the 2–4 min samples were also present. After 9 min of reaction, octahedra had formed although their surfaces might not have been atomically flat. It might have taken a few more minutes of surface reconstruction for the nanocrystals to establish their final sharp faces. This investigation further reveals that metallic polyhedral nanocrystal formation does not really operate through growth along different crystallographic directions, such as the notion of growth rate along the <100> direction relative to that of the <111> direction, or the value of R, normally used to describe the evolution of crystal geometry.

In our previous work, TB was used as an assisted stabilizer in the citrate premixture method to synthesize large sized Au NCs. Actually, the amino groups of TB are able to interact with Au(I) ions and Au atoms and TB as a stabilizer is stronger than citrate in the synthesis of Au NCs. Moreover, in the current work, we found that the TB concentration has a significant effect on the morphology of the Au NCs at room temperature (Fig. 3). For example, the optimal TB concentration for the synthesis of 87 nm Au NCs is 2.50 mM (Fig. 3c), which means the molar ratio of TB to HAuCl4 is 4.0. When the TB concentration is below 2.50 mM (Fig. 3a and b), the molar ratio of TB to HAuCl4 is less than 4.0. Few triangle, rod and other shape by-products are obtained, exhibiting a low extinction spectrum intensity, broader SPR bands, and a higher baseline. The morphology of Au NCs is similar to the lack of H2O2 in the previous work on the synthesis of citrate-stabilized Au NCs, which means the lack of TB caused secondary nucleation. When the TB concentration is above 2.50 mM (Fig. 3d to g), the molar ratio of TB to HAuCl4 is more than 4.0. Some Au NCs show irregular polygon shapes, the extinction spectra peaks become broader and red shift. Noting that the amino groups of TB were able to interact with Au(I) ions and Au atoms strongly, the emergence of irregular polygon Au NCs indicates that the excess TB can lead to a change of Au NCs morphology. The mechanism of the specific morphology change due to the excessive TB concentration still needs to be further studied.

The effect of PEGylation and drug conjugation on the particle size was also determined by AFM and DLS (Figure 5). The AFM images indicate that there is no significant change in the size of the nanoparticles at any stage. Their hydrodynamic diameter in suspension, however, shows an increase in the particle size upon PEGylation and drug conjugation. The naked 25 nm AuNPs demonstrate increases from 24.4 nm in size to 35.1 and 37.4 nm after PEGylation and platinum conjugation, respectively (Figure 5). The hydrodynamic diameter of the 55 nm AuNPs increases from 55.6 nm to 73.2 and 75.9 nm and that of the 90 nm AuNPs from 89.2 nm to 107.2 and 106.0 nm upon PEGylation and conjugation, respectively. The increase in the size after PEGylation can be used to determine the thickness of the PEG layer; however, any polydispersity in the size distribution makes this difficult. The larger hydrodynamic diameters yielded by DLS for the latter two stages of assembly, compared to those observed for the naked AuNPs, are due to interactions between the solvent and the covalently surface-bound PEG. This effect has been previously observed for PEGylated AuNPs, where hydrodynamic interactions are increased for large PEG linkers. The polymer monolayer decreases the mobility of the nanoparticle, most likely because of solvent interactions. The absence of aggregation when platinum is conjugated to the AuNP is an improvement on what we have previously published, where a 4.5-fold increase in the size was observed in both the solution and solid state. This is because, previously, the platinum drug used was the active component of oxaliplatin, {Pt(1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane)}, which has a cyclohexane-based ligand and may cause aggregation through hydrophobic self-interactions. Using the active component of cisplatin introduces polar ammine ligands that can hydrogen bond with water molecules and help retain stability in solution.

Control over the position and orientation of gold NRs is critically important to tune their collective plasmonic properties for use in device applications. The selective immobilization of citrate-stabilized gold NRs on substrates modified with PEG together with demonstrated capabilities in fabricating nanoscale patterns of polymer thin films, open up a range of opportunities for the spatially defined assembly of plasmonic nanostructures. Herein, a versatile nanofabrication technique is utilized to prepare one-dimensional nanoscale patterns of end-grafted PEG layers. The method, sometimes referred to as electrospin nanolithography or organic nanowire lithography, relies on electrospun nanofibers as masks for selective material removal during oxygen plasma etching (Fig. 4 a) [37,41]. Near-field electrospinning enables spatially defined and highly aligned deposition of nanofibers allowing fabrication of linear patterns of end-grafted PEG layers in regions that are protected by the nanofibers. The removal of nanofibers through repeated washing results in stripes of PEG with widths that are defined by the diameter of the fiber and etching conditions. Spotting a droplet of the suspension containing the citrate-stabilized gold NRs followed by washing in water under sonication results in linear arrays of the particles (Fig. 4b). This result further highlights the specific interaction of citrate-stabilized gold NRs with end-grafted PEG layers, since rods selectively bound to the patterned regions with extremely low levels of non-specific adsorption to the background regions. We prepared a series of stripes with line widths ranging from ∼400 nm to ∼50 nm by varying the diameter of the nanofiber used to mask the underlying PEG layer (Fig. 4c). The width of the pattern not only determined the number of rods immobilized per line width, but also affected the orientation of the rods. At wide lines, the orientation of the rods was mostly random and a significant fraction of the rods assembled with their long axis perpendicular to the direction of the pattern. This kind of packing was also observed for the assembly of mercaptopropanesulfonate functionalized NRs on patterns of poly(2-vinylpyridine) surrounded by polystyrene regions [42]. Such assemblies likely result from the minimization of the interface between the rods and native oxide that is found in the background regions. The rods exhibited end-to-end type assemblies with single particle per width, when the width of the lines approached the length of the rods.

The worm-like nanorods are also characterized by other optical methods of fluorescence measurement and resonance light scattering (RLS) spectroscopy. Fig. 8 a shows the fluorescence spectra of a series of gold nanorods and worm-like nanorods (the same nanorods appeared in Fig. 2) at the same concentration after excitation at 480 nm. As the LPW increases from 756 nm to 942 nm, no significant change of the emission peaks (either the wavelength or the intensity) was observed. The result indicates that the worm-like gold nanorods exhibit similar fluorescence characteristics to the conventional ones.

In a typical synthesis, the amount of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution and gold nanoparticles is 4 ml and 5 mg respectively. To learn more about the formation of multi-pods Au/FeO(OH) nanostructures, we also characterized the size and morphology of Au/FeO(OH) nanostructures obtained from their synthesis using different amounts of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution and gold nanoparticles. By keeping the amount of gold nanoparticles at 5 mg, when the amount of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution was 2 ml and 5 ml respectively, multi-pods Au/FeO(OH) nanostructures were too obtained. Fig. 4a is a typical SEM image of Au/FeO(OH) nanostructures prepared in the presence of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution (2 ml) and gold nanoparticles (5 mg), the length of FeO(OH) pods is in the range of 310–530 nm, their width is in the range of 100–265 nm and their thickness is in the range of 95–135 nm, and the gold nanoparticles are supported on them (as shown in Fig. 4b), which shows that the size of FeO(OH) pods decrease as the amount of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution decrease. When the amount of (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution was kept at 4 ml, and the amount of gold nanoparticles decreased to 2 mg, we found that the products were all multi-pods Au/FeO(OH) nanostructures yet (see Supporting information Fig. S1). Besides, we examined the effect of the hydrothermal reaction time yet. When the reaction time was decreased to 12 h or 24 h, and the other experiment conditions were kept unchanged, we found that the morphology of Au/FeO(OH) were also multipods (Fig. 5a and b). But, as shown in Fig. 5b, the length of FeO(OH) pods is only in the range of 650–1000 nm, and their width is in the range of 180–530 nm, which is smaller than that of FeO(OH) pods obtained in the typical synthesis. In the absence of CTAB and gold nanoparticles, and the other experiment conditions were same as the typical synthesis, the products have both FeO(OH) hollow spheres and multipods (Fig. 6a), when (NH4)3[FeF6] aqueous solution was replaced by (NH4)3[FeCl6] or Na3[FeF6] aqueous solution, the products were FeO(OH) nanoparticles and FeO(OH) multipods respectively (see Supporting information Fig. S2), but only in the absence of gold nanoparticles, the products were all FeO(OH) multipods (Fig. 6b), these results show that F− ions and CTAB molecules all play an important role in the formation of FeO(OH) multipods. Besides, the reflection peaks strength of FeO(OH) multipods obtained only in the absence of gold nanoparticles is obviously stronger than that of FeO(OH) in Au/FeO(OH) obtained in typical synthesis. Similar case is also found in the XRD patterns of Fe2O3 and Au/Fe2O3 nanostructures (see Supporting information Fig. S3 and Fig. S4).

Previously, PDDA-mediated polyol synthesis has been employed to grow Au octahedra. Interestingly, the introduction of Ag and Pd foreign ions in the similar reactions has led to completely different shapes. To further elucidate the effects of Ag and Pd ions on the shape-selective growth of Au nanoparticles, we conducted a series of control experiments by varying the concentrations of Pd(II) and Ag(I) while keeping AuCl4− concentration at a constant. Figure 8A shows the Au octahedra enclosed by {111} facets prepared from reactions of HAuCl4 (0.9 mM) and PDDA in EG. When a small amount of Pd(II) (0.06 mM) was added to the reaction, the gold nanocrystals evolved from octahedra to apex truncated octahedra and triangular plates (Figure 8B). These truncations are accompanied by the appearance of {100} facets, which can be attributed to the deposition of Pd. Replacing Pd(II) with Ag(I) showed a different way of truncation. Figures 8C shows Au nanocrystals synthesized in the absence of Pd(II) but with Ag(I) ions at a concentration of 0.06 mM, in which case edge truncated octahedra were formed (Figure 8C). Because the truncated edges of the octahedra are {110} facets, this result indicates that the addition of Ag ions promotes the formation of {110} facets of Au nanocrystals. Reactions with higher concentration of Pd ions (0.12 mM) in the presence of Ag ions were also performed. Figure 8D−F shows the nanocrystals obtained from reactions at ratios of Au:Pd:Ag = 15:2:0.4, 15:2:1.6, and 15:2:8, respectively. Truncated THHs (140 nm), truncated DTPs (250 nm), and bipyramids (130 nm) were formed at these three ratios, but particle sizes are larger than those obtained at low concentration of Pd(II). An SEM image of the truncated THHs at higher magnification showing clearly the different facets is presented in Figure S5. It should be noted that the truncated THHs obtained in this case (Figure 8D) have a higher degree of coverage of {111} facets than those obtained at lower concentration of Pd(II) (Figure 4). In addition, the yields of DTPs and bipyramids are lower than those obtained at a Pd(II) concentration of 0.06 mM. Comparison of the nanocrystals obtained at different Ag(I) and Pd(II) concentrations (Ag/Pd = 0.2:1, Figure 8D; 0.4:1, Figure 4; 0.8:1, Figure 8E; and 1.6:1, Figure 1) shows that the coverage of {310} facets increases with the Ag(I)/Pd(II) ratio until the particles are enclosed entirely by {310} facets. This trend holds at low concentrations of Ag(I) (<0.1 mM). Reactions at higher concentration of Ag(I) lead to the formation of multiple-twinned bipyramids.

The UV–visible spectra obtained for the Au NRs, Au–TPDT NRs and Au/Ag–TPDT NRs showed that the optical properties of the Au NRs were influenced by the Ag on the Au NRs (Fig. 1 ). The deposition of Ag on the surface of the Au NRs showed about a blue shift in the longitudinal plasmon band when compared to the Au NRs. The as-prepared Au NRs showed a transverse plasmon band at 511 nm and a longitudinal plasmon band at 796 nm (Fig. 1(a)). The Au–TPDT NRs showed a transverse plasmon band at 511 nm and a longitudinal plasmon band at 766 nm (Fig. 1(b)) and the Au/Ag–TPDT NRs showed a transverse plasmon band at 501 nm and a longitudinal plasmon band at 678 nm (Fig. 1(c)). A blue shift of 118 nm was observed for the longitudinal band and 10 nm at the transverse band for the Au/Ag–TPDT NRs when compared to the Au NRs. A blue shift of 30 nm in the longitudinal plasmon band was observed for the Au–TPDT NRs and no shift was observed in the transverse plasmon band is due to the change in the local refractive index and dielectric of the medium after the dispersion of TPDT silicate sol–gel matrix on the Au NRs. As the Ag was coated on the surface of Au NRs, the longitudinal surface plasmon band was blue-shifted along with a small blue shift in the transverse band for the Au/Ag–TPDT NRs when compared to the Au NRs. The blue shift in the longitudinal and transverse bands of the Au NRs was observed due to the change in the local refractive index and dielectric of the medium surrounding the Au NRs after the homogeneous deposition of Ag on the Au NRs and a decrease in the overall aspect ratio of the Au NRs .

TEM images of the AuNRs assembly from these two types of AuNRs are shown in Fig. 5a–c. It can be found that most of the AuNRs were linked into a distinct ES motif. Fig. 5b shows that the side face of a nanorod can bind one, two, three and even four rods by the ES assembled mode. Among them, we observe that most ES-oriented ensembles were in the configuration of one rod connected to two or three rods, which may be attributed to an aspect ratio of 3.5 for AuNRs. Besides, few assembly motifs are in the configuration shown in Fig. 5c. It is interesting to note that the plasmon absorption (Fig. 5d) of these ES assemblies exhibit a great red shift for both the longitudinal plasmon peak and the transverse plasmon peak, which red shift to 980 nm and 550 nm at 90 min respectively. Such a red shift phenomenon of the plasmon absorption might be understood in terms of plasmon interaction between the longitudinal and transverse modes of the AuNRs. Considering the complex configurations, further study is pending for this special phenomenon. Counting the rods in several TEM images reveals that ES assembly motif is found in nearly 50% of the whole rods, while both control samples are randomly dispersed (Fig. 5e).

Gold nanoparticles were synthesized by reduction of tetrachloroauric acid with sodium citrate as described by Turkewish et al. with certain modifications. A citrate concentration appears to be very crucial for preparation and controlling particle size of the gold nanoparticles . During synthesis of gold nanoparticles, tetrachloroauric acid concentration was kept constant (10 mg) and citrate concentration was varied (1.54 × 10−3 to 1.54 × 10−2 M) to get desired particle size. For obtaining lower particle size gold NP, higher citrate ion concentration was required and vice versa. The data is shown in Table 1 . The average particle sizes of gold nanoparticles were optimized to 15 ± 2.30 nm, 50 ± 5.65 nm, 100 ± 5.56 nm and 200 ± 7.56 nm. The data shown is average of five batches. Polydispersity index of 15, 50, 100 and 200 nm average size gold NP was 0.44 ± 0.05, 0.42 ± 0.08, 0.36 ± 0.07 and 0.32 ± 0.06, respectively (Table 1). Lower the concentration of sodium citrate is, more gold atoms will aggregate into a nanoparticle, which results in the increase of diameters . Gold nanoparticles showed relatively low polydispersity index (Table 1). Gold nanoparticles showed negative zeta potential (Table 1). Increase in particle size showed slightly decrease in zeta potential. This is due to varying citrate ion concentration used during synthesis of gold NP. Zeta potential indicated negative surface properties of the gold nanoparticles with good stability in suspension. Nanoparticles with a zeta potential above (±) 30 mV have been shown to be stable in suspension, as the surface charge prevents aggregation of the particles .

The morphology of SGN/Au hybrid was characterized by TEM and HRTEM. The samples for TEM observation were prepared by sonication of the as-prepared SGN/Au modified electrode in water to transfer the hybrid from electrode surface to water. Figure 1a shows TEM image of SGN/Au hybrid. It can be observed that the two-dimensional graphene sheets have been decorated with highly distributed Au nanoparticles. The individual Au nanoparticles (black dots) with a diameter of about 3–5 nm (as shown in Fig. 1b) were well-separated from each other and well spread out on the graphene sheets, indicating that Au nanoparticles have been extensively assembled on SGN upon strong electrostatic interactions between both components. From the edges of the hybrid (Fig. 1a), a typical flake-like sheet with layered morphology was observed, indicative of unique graphene nanosheets.

XRD measurements also show that particle growth proceeds via adding more gold atoms along the preferential planes. Figure 5 shows the XRD patterns of the samples A−E. For each pattern three peaks were observed which can be assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) diffraction peaks of fcc gold metal. It is noteworthy that the intensity ratios between the (200) and the (111) diffractions, I(200)I(111), for the prepared samples are much smaller than the conventional bulk intensity ratio (∼0.53),26 and the ratio decreases as particle size increases; I(200)I(111) = 0.32, 0.29, 0.23, and 0.09 for samples B, C, D, and E, respectively (the value for sample A could not be obtained because of poor spectral quality). These observations further revealed that surfaces of the nanoparticles are primarily composed of {111} facets, and the particles preferentially grow along <111> directions as particle size increases. On the other hand, the full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of the XRD peak can enable us to evaluate the size variation of the samples. The fwhm of the (111) peak was gradually decreased from 0.6 (sample A) to 0.4 (sample E). As confirmed by TEM measurements, this result implies that the size of the nanoparticles increases from sample A to E.

The concentration of Au3+ is high near the Au particle surface. Therefore, Ag wires are dissolved and broken through the above reaction. Large spherical Au particles do not melt; they remain as excentered Au cores after melting Ag/Au alloy nanowires. On the other hand, small polygonal Au particles having a lower melting point are fused and aggregate to form excentered spherical Au cores during melting Ag/Au alloy nanowires. When Au@Ag/Au particles grow to a critical size (∼400 nm), they become stable for thermal annealing so that monodispersed sizes of Au@Ag/Au particles are finally produced.

Fig. 6 is a display of SEM micrographs of 1-D nanoGUMBOS prepared from [MImProSH][TPB] GUMBOS using an AAO template. The resulting nanorods have narrowly-dispersed diameters in the 240 to 280 nm range. These diameters are noticeably larger than the claimed 200 nm pore size of the AAO discs used as templates. A recent report observed a similar swelling behavior for nanorods after removal from the AAO template. The evolution of core–shell 1-D nanoGUMBOS built around [MImProSH][TPB] as a core material is displayed in Fig. 7. Gold-seeded nanorods (Fig. 7B) were obtained after 48 h of immersion in gold seed solution. Shown in Fig. 7C are illustrative gold-coated rod-shaped [MImProSH][TPB] nanoGUMBOS.

The surface morphologies of the ITO/TiO2 and ITO/TiO2/CdS electrodes were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), as shown in Figure 2 A and 2B in order. After TiO2 film was produced on an ITO electrode, plenty of nanoparticles with an average size of 25±3 nm and a large number of mesopores could be observed (Figure 2 A). After CdS QDs modification, the size of the nanoparticles on the electrode surface increased to 31±4 nm and the pore size decreased obviously, which pointed that the CdS QDs had successfully adhered on the TiO2 film (Figure 2 B). Besides, the color change from white to yellow of the electrode surfaces further confirmed successful fabrication of the ITO/TiO2 and ITO/TiO2/CdS electrodes.

Although microfluidic devices (and other flow reactors) can, in theory, be numbered up ad infinitum to generate unlimited amounts of nanomaterial, the successful numbering up of microfluidic devices to generate a gram of functionalized nanomaterials has not been demonstrated. In addition, despite at least two recognized gram-scale AuNR batch syntheses being published, the development of a convenient gram-scale syntheses for functionalized gold nanoparticles remains a pressing challenge. In contrast, the synthesis of a gram of gold nanorods with controlled aspect ratios in the millifluidic reactor can be achieved with no modifications to the original synthesis simply by running a single reactor continuously.

Fig. 2a shows the UV–vis absorption spectra of GNRs. GNRs have unique and tunable optical properties which are related to two distinct plasmon bands named transverse band and longitudinal band. The long wavelength plasmon band originates from the longitudinal mode of oscillation of the free electrons along the long axis of the rod, while the short wavelength plasmon band originates from the transverse mode perpendicular to the former one. As shown in Fig. 2a, GNRs exhibit two well-defined absorption bands, the transverse band located at 520 nm and the longitudinal band located at 702 nm. Fig. 2b shows the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of GNRs synthesized by the seed-mediated growth method in the presence of CTAB. It can be seen that the prepared GNRs are nearly monodisperse and homogeneous. The average size is about 58×24 nm, respectively. GO was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 3, when the C 1 s XPS spectra was deconvoluted, the peaks at 284.6, 286.9, and 288.7 eV are associated with C3C, C3OH, and CåO, respectively.

To explore the possibility of tuning the aspect ratio of gold NRs and study the effects of different aromatic additives on gold NR growth, the acid forms of those aromatic additives such as salicylic acid and its common chemical variants are employed (Figure S1). The amount of each additive is optimized so that the NR growth solution is not too viscous to allow the needed solute diffusion at a CTAB concentration of ∼0.05 M. As shown in Figure 2, gold NRs with negligible shape impurities are obtained by using 5-bromosalicylic acid or 2,6-dihydroxybenzoic acid as the additive, with NR dimensions of (46.0 ± 3.0 nm) × (12.0 ± 1.0 nm) and (51.5 ± 3.0 nm) × (15.5 ± 1.5 nm), respectively (Figures 2a–d, S4, S5). However, a small fraction of spherical nanoparticles does exist in the as-synthesized gold NR sample using the additive 4-methylsalicylic acid (Figures 2e,f and S6), although the dimensions ((51.0 ± 3.0 nm) × (14.0 ± 1.5 nm)) of the NRs are nearly identical to those obtained with the additive 5-bromosalicylic acid. The amount of shape impurities is also reflected by intensities of the absorption shoulder around 545 nm in the extinction spectra (Figure 2i). The narrow LSPR peaks centered at about 750 nm for additives 5-bromosalicylic acid (full width at half-maximum, fwhm = 104 nm) and 4-methylsalicylic acid (fwhm = 97 nm) and around 730 nm for additive 2,6-dihydroxybenzoic acid (fwhm = 93 nm) further confirm the monodispersity of the gold NRs. HRTEM images show that the NRs are single-crystalline, growing along the [001] direction (Figure 2g, h), similar to the shorter NRs prepared using aromatic sodium salt additives (Figure 1c,f).

To understand the morphological transformation, the crystalline analysis of gold NDs and their resulting NRs after heating was performed by means of high resolution electron microscopy (HRTEM). Fig. 6 a is the HRTEM image of the tip of gold NDs and the inset in the figure corresponds to its FFT pattern. The FFT pattern could be indexed as the [0 1 1]-projection of face-centered cubic structure and confirms that the crystalline facets of the gold atoms in the tip of gold NDs are of the {1 1 0} type. Similar results were also obtained in the analysis of the gold NRs generated by heating the above gold NDs (Fig. 6b). These TEM data suggests that the atoms in the tips of gold NDs tend to diffuse into the lateral sides during heating and reconstruction simultaneously occurs as shown in Fig. 7 . Because the surface of gold NDs was encapsulated by CATB micelles, heating could result in the significant loss of both the stability of the micelle structures and their protecting ability in the tips in comparison with that in the lateral sides. It has been reported that the AR of gold NRs in solution decrease with increasing temperature [30]; it is attributed to the reduction only in their length from the TEM images, but their width dose not change with temperature. In some cases, the AR and the shape change occurred as a result of high-energy laser heating [31,32]. When gold NRs are modified with PEG brushers and dispersed in poly(methyl methacrylate), thermal annealing of the nanocomposite film results in a blue shift of SPR in a vacuum oven in the range of 60 °C–200 °C, caused by a decrease in the length of the NR [33]. When heating at 60 °C, the blue shift is only 17 nm after 8 days. At 150 °C, a much stronger blue shift is observed after 30 min of annealing. On the other hand, the stability of the surface atoms in the {1 1 0} facets of the tip could be enhanced by chemical modification of cysteine, even in protection with the soft micelle structure of CATB at 75 °C. Therefore, the shape transformation of gold NDs is totally inhibited. Peculiarly, the shape transformation in SDS solution spontaneously appears at RT without any heating. Anionic SDS is seldom used as the stabilizer in the synthesis of gold NPs because of its weak protecting ability [34]; it has been shown that gold NPs could be surrounded by the monolayer of SDS in our previous studies [35,36]. The structure of the SDS monolayer is not denser, so the reagent may easily penetrate through it and reach the surface of gold NPs, resulting in the occurrence of the catalyzed reaction at RT. For example, gold NPs protected by SDS could be used as the catalyst for hydrogenation of anthracene with hydride at RT [36]. The hydride in the aqueous phase can easily penetrate through the SDS layer and subsequently transfer electrons to gold NPs. The blue shift of the SPR band was observed immediately because the increase of electron density of gold NPs. At the same time, electron transfer-induced hydrogen atoms from hydride will react with nearby anthracene molecules to give 9,10-dihydroanthracene. Further, it has been reported that the stability and transformations of heated gold NRs is studied by molecular dynamics simulations in the range of 400 k–1000 K [37]. Their calculation results indicate that the least stable NR was found to be the NR with the largest {1 1 0} surface, while the NR with approximately equal surface areas of {1 0 0} and {1 1 0} surface was the most stable. Gold ND which we prepared has higher areas of {1 1 0} surface in the tips than that of the original gold NR. Therefore, it is possible that the transformation of gold NDs could be carried out at lower temperature than that of gold NRs. Moreover, the surface gold atoms in the {1 1 0} facets of the tip of gold NDs could spontaneously diffuse into their lateral side at RT because of the weak stabilizing ability of SDS. Thus, the new gold NRs with a smaller AR were formed.

To allow correlating previous results with the stabilization properties of colloidal solutions of AuNPs and to avoid any chemical modification of the polymers, we separately synthesized AuNPs and subsequently mixed them with the polymer. The AuNPs were synthesized by reduction of HAuCl4 with NaBH4. Experimental conditions were set in order to get these negatively charged NPs with an average radius of ca. 4 ± 2 nm. NPs surrounded by a low amount of ions issued from this reduction process. This will then allow a fast grafting of the polymer at their surface without the need of ligand exchange as is necessary in the Brust–Schiffrin method. Those AuNPs are sensitive to any increase of the ionic strength or change in pH, inducing charge neutralization and then aggregation. Thus, increasing ionic strength of the AuNPs dispersion modified the color of the solution from red to purple. This corresponded to a large change of the UV–visible spectrum of the solution: the surface plasmon band (SPB) of the NPs initially at 520 nm (associated with well-dispersed AuNPs) decreased strongly and was accompanied by an increase in absorbance at higher wavelength (suggesting aggregated AuNPs).

The prepared chitosan-capped gold nanoparticles possess all the requirements to be engulfed by the cells without causing any morphological or functional disruption: the particles are spherical, have a size of about 50 nm and are positively charged due to the quaternary amines present in the polymeric structure. Moreover, the functional groups presented on their surface can contribute to further nanoparticle conjugation with various molecules such as insulin or cisplatin for desired applications such as nanocarriers or drug delivery [41,42]. The comparative viability tests presented in this study come in agreement with other reported observations that gold nanoparticles citrate- or CTAB-coating has a dramatic impact on cell viability, development and functionality [43,44]. On the contrary, we demonstrated that chitosan-coating confers biocompatibility for the particles, as they show negligible toxicity for the cells during 19 h.

The LSPR properties of metal nanoparticles can be described by the Mie theory which gives analytical and exact solutions of the Maxwell equations for a classical, spherical nanoparticle with the multipolar expansion of the electromagnetic fields. Here we describe the overview of the LSPR properties of PdNSs. Figure 1A shows the dependence of the extinction spectrum on the particle diameter (d) of PdNSs surrounded by water (n = 1.333) for a range of d = 10–200 nm simulated on the basis of the Mie theory. PdNSs smaller than 40 nm in diameter do not exhibit any LSPR peaks in the wavelength region longer than 200 nm. The larger PdNSs (d ≥ 50 nm) show a single LSPR peak within the near-ultraviolet (UV) region, and those larger than 90 nm in diameter exhibit multiple, typically three, peaks within the range of 200–1200 nm. These three peaks can be attributed to dipolar, quadrupolar, and octupolar LSPR modes in order from the longer to shorter wavelength region (Figure 1B). We notice that the band of the dipolar mode of PdNSs is much broader than those of AuNSs and AgNSs (see Figure S1 in Supporting Information) and it broadens further with shifting to a longer wavelength region. This is because the imaginary part of the dielectric function of Pd is larger than those of Au and Ag and increases further with increasing wavelength because of an interband transition (see Figure S2 in Supporting Information).
